dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh my gosh, B, did you see this Guild Education thing? This is incredible!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh my gosh, B, did you see this Guild Education thing? This is incredible!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Incredible, A? Really? That's what you got from that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Incredible, A? Really? That's what you got from that?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah! I mean, come on, 64 million frontline workers needing education? And companies like Walmart, they're actually stepping up. Offering degrees for like, what, a dollar a day?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah! I mean, come on, sixty four million frontline workers needing education? And companies like Walmart, they're actually stepping up. Offering degrees for like, what, a dollar a day?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Guild estimates that 64 million frontline and low-income workers will need further education in order to compete in an increasingly automated world. ... For example, the nation's largest employer Walmart's Live Better U program covers all tuition costs after financial aid, with the employee contributing only $1 a day.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: A dollar a day, sure. And then Carlson says, what, it "lifted their profits, recruitment and retainment"? Uh, yeah, that's why they're doing it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A dollar a day, sure. And then Carlson says, what, it lifted their profits, recruitment and retainment? Uh, yeah, that's why they're doing it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It wasnt them just giving themselves a pat on the back it had lifted their profits, recruitment and retainment, she explained.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But itâ€™s still good for the workers! They get degrees, new skills. That's, um, upward mobility!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it's still good for the workers! They get degrees, new skills. That's, um, upward mobility!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, "upward mobility" that conveniently, uh, makes them better for the company. Stephanie Ruhle is right, analysts aren't asking about "good," they're asking about the bottom line.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, upward mobility that conveniently, uh, makes them better for the company. Stephanie Ruhle is right, analysts aren't asking about good, they're asking about the bottom line.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When you listen to any analyst call, Ive never heard an analyst ask about the good a company is doing,countered Ruhle.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But the article says it's not just a pat on the back. It leads to higher retention, better recruitment, you know? And employee satisfaction jumped 15%!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the article says it's not just a pat on the back. It leads to higher retention, better recruitment, you know? And employee satisfaction jumped fifteen percent!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The article mentions higher retention and recruitment rates, but does not contain any information about employee satisfaction or a 15% jump.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Please. Employee satisfaction surveys. Come on. What, uh, what do you expect them to say when their employer is footing the bill?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Please. Employee satisfaction surveys. Come on. What, uh, what do you expect them to say when their employer is footing the bill?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So you're saying it's purely cynical? That it's not genuinely helping anyone but the, uh, corporations? That's just... that's a really jaded view, B.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So you're saying it's purely cynical? That it's not genuinely helping anyone but the, uh, corporations? That's just... that's a really jaded view, B.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Jaded? No, A, it's realistic. A $1.2 billion valuation doesn't come from altruism. It comes from, like, making companies money.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Jaded? No, A, it's realistic. A one point two dollars billion valuation doesn't come from altruism. It comes from, like, making companies money.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The article does not mention a $1.2 billion valuation. It states: "the company has attracted over $70 million in funding from firms like Bessemer Venture Partners, Cowboy Ventures and Silicon Valley Bank."

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But if it's a win-win, where the company profits and the employee gets educated, why is that bad?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But if it's a win-win, where the company profits and the employee gets educated, why is that bad?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Because it's not for the employee. It's using the employee's desire for education to, uh, boost the corporate brand and, surprise, future IPOs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Because it's not for the employee. It's using the employee's desire for education to, uh, boost the corporate brand and, surprise, future IPOs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, so the IPO is the only reason? Not, like, improving lives?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, so the I P O is the only reason? Not, like, improving lives?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: They want to change the tax code for gig workers, A. It's about incentivizing companies, not just, uh, doing right by drivers. It's always about the incentives for them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They want to change the tax code for gig workers, A. It's about incentivizing companies, not just, uh, doing right by drivers. It's always about the incentives for them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That's because the tax code doesn't allow companies to provide nontaxable education assistance to those workers. Lobbying to change this tax incentive might be the company's greatest hurdle yet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But those drivers still get an education!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But those drivers still get an education!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: An education they'd have to pay taxes on because the company won't get a break. Think about that for a second.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: An education they'd have to pay taxes on because the company won't get a break. Think about that for a second.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That's because the tax code doesn't allow companies to provide nontaxable education assistance to those workers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: You know what, I just think you're missing the bigger picture here. This is a positive step.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You know what, I just think you're missing the bigger picture here. This is a positive step.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, you're missing the picture. It's, uh, just capitalism wearing a very, very thin disguise of philanthropy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, you're missing the picture. It's, uh, just capitalism wearing a very, very thin disguise of philanthropy.
